did.head: Collection Summary

repository.label: Location
repository.corpname: Science, Technology, & Business Division Library of Congress

did.abstract: Correspondence, blueprints and manufactures information for early French and foreign aircraft and dirigibles, reports of accidents involving flyers and balloonists, World War I aerial photographs and intelligence reports, a series of French cartoons, drawings, graphs, charts, diagrams of equipment, maps, newspapers, printed material, and photographs. The materials in the collection were evidently assembled by staff of the magazine L’Aerophile which was published by Georges Besançon in collaboration with Union Aérophile de France. Subjects include aeronautics chiefly in Europe and the U.S., aeronautics corporations, air shows, aviators, balloons, bombs and missiles, commercial airlines, dirigibles, gliders, hydroplanes, medical aviation, military aeronautics, model aircraft, parachutes, propellers, record flights, and research and testing of aircraft. Individuals represented include Henry Harley "Hap" Arnold, Georges Besançon, Amelia Earhart, Charles Lindbergh, and William "Billy" Mitchell.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Collection purchased by Library of Congress in 1969.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The materials in the collection were evidently assembled by staff of the magazine L’Aerophile which was published by Georges Besançon in collaboration with Union Aérophile de France.

processinfo.head: Location
processinfo.p: Unclassed ST&B, TRS (Science, Technology, and Business Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.)

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Request in Science, Technology, & Business Division reference desk, Adams Building, 5th Floor (ask for Tech Reports 202 707-5655)

userestrict.head: Restrictions
userestrict.p: Inquire at Science, Technology, & Business Division reference desk, Adams Building, 5th Floor, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

altformavail.head: Electronic Format
altformavail.p: An enhanced Web presentation of the L’Aerophile Collection is available on the Library of Congress Web site at http://www.loc.gov/rr/scitech/trs/trslaerophile.html.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: The L’Aerophile Collection, Science, Technology, & Business Division, Library of Congress.

bioghist.head: Background
bioghist.p: In January 1893 the French journalist and balloonist Georges Besançon (1866-1934), in collaboration with the Union Aérophile de France, began publishing a monthly illustrated revue , L'Aerophile (published 1893-1947). Quickly, L'Aerophile became one of the premier journals of the early history of aviation. The first years were devoted to balloonists and the importance of meteorology on ballooning (for example, atmospheric effects on equipment, instruments, and humans). In later years, as artificial wings, gliders, man- and engine-powered planes were developed, the magazine brought their stories to the public. The materials in the collection were evidently assembled by staff of the magazine L’Aerophile.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The fifteen thousand or so items contained in the 152 boxes of the Library of Congress collection include blueprints and manufactures' information of early French and foreign aircraft and dirigibles, reports of accidents involving flyers and balloonists, aerial photographs from World War I, and a series of French cartoons from the period 1909 - 1912 related to aviation. The collection also contains hundreds of photographs of early aviators and designers, including pictures of Charles Lindbergh and his wife Anne Morrow being feted in Paris during their European trip of 1933. A large number of L'Aerophile images appeared in the National Air and Space Museum's major exhibition in 2003 celebrating the centennial of the Wright brothers' first flight, titled the Wright Brothers & the Invention of the Aerial Age.

arrangement.head: Series Description
arrangement.p: The L'Aerophile Collection is arranged in six Series:

scopecontent.p: Early photographs, handbooks, catalogs, newspaper articles, blueprints, intelligence reports, and other publications relating to the early years of aviation, including balloon flight, airplanes and aviators.

arrangement.p: Arranged in boxes, folders, and envelopes.

did.unittitle: A miscellaneous collection of black and white photos of the first aviation designers, philanthropists, test-pilots and first American aviators - Wilbur and Orville Wright, Thomas DeWitt Milling, Howard Hughes, etc. Pictures of first female aviators - Harriet Quimby, Amelia Earhart are also included. Early pictures of the U.S. Army Air Service (chiefs, pilots, crews and group pictures) and U.S. Army Air Corps in California, with Major Henry H. Arnold.
A New York Times article (1926) about young Henry H. Arnold, who later became the commanding general of the Army Air Forces (AAF) during World War II (includes photographs). 1926.
A booklet: "The H. H. Arnold Collection" (3 copies), along with photos of airplanes in the air.
Collection dite "Au ballon" by M.Leon Bartou, Paris. 8-9-10 Mai 1935.
Aerostation: a catalogue of books and engravings illustrating the evolution of the airship and the aeroplane to 1938. Maggs Bros.Ltd, London. 1940
Aeronautik: auction catalog in German illustrating items such as coins, porcelain, small books, fans, etc., with images related to aviation. Luzern, Schweiz. 26-27 June 1934.
Calendars (German aircraft manufacturers) 1926-1935. Includes 12 German sheet calendars with photos.
France. Aerial landscape photos and parts of Paris. 1930-1940.
France. Photographs taken from a balloon. No date.
Le palais du Bey in Tunis.
Courcelles-Epayelles - a good aerial view of a French village.
German, Italy, and Spain photos. No date.
Balloon View of Girard College, Philadelphia, (Samuel A. King, aeronaut). July 4, 1893.
Balloon View of San Diego City's Harbor. 1923.
Aerial view of countryside and cities in France, Germany and Switzerland. 1890-1910.
Aerial views ( Versailles, Château de Champlâtreux, Vaux le Vicomte, Rochefort en Yvelines).
Aerial views in Africa: Egyptian pyramids and ruins in Sahara desert; running elephants in Tchad.
Tigre river and Baghdad city. Dubrovnik in Croatia. Pompeii amphitheater in Italy.
Publications, USA: A-E; Publications, USA: F-N.
Notes on Liberty Engine Ignition System. 1919.
History of the 96th Aero Squadron - First American Day Bomb Bardment.
The Ambassador, a brochure about the first modern civil aircraft, its features and specifications. Hampshire, England. July, 1948.
Civil Aviation: Industry Studies - Report of the Air coordinating committee, Washington DC. 1947.
Civil Aviation: Industry Studies - Analysis of Air Transportation Industry by Henry Beecken. October, 1942.
French intelligence reports on WWI German airplanes, translated into English for US intelligence; Loessel paper (critique).
French aeronautical publications (Ae-Av), misc., some prior to WWI.
French aeronautical publications (Ae-E), including aviators, balloons, dirigibles, some prior to WWI.
French newspapers, 1911; special report on German gliders, 1937; Propeller shafts, French, 1932; Engines, Hispano-Suzia, misc. articles and magazine clippings (E-Mi).
Small aircraft; transatlantic flights; international flights; Newspapers, French, 1910.
Publications from Britain; propellers; automobiles; trains; flight training schools.
Publications from Germany, Japan, Italy; parachutes; meteorology; military aviation.
Newspaper clippings: 'Plane News' 1918-1919; Spanish language publications 1912; French publications 1920-1927, 1937.

Model building (blueprints).
Blueprints: Allison Eng; Navy Bureau of Aeronautics (1923); Wittemann airliner, 1936; Kite balloons.
Lindbergh, Charles. L'aerophile photographs, newspaper clippings, portraits.
Handbook of instructions for airplane designers. 1920-1922.

scopecontent.p: Contains guides, studies, drawings, publicity, books, and albums relating to early aviation companies and aviation-related events.

scopecontent.p: Photographs, drawings, and charts pertaining to early aviation in the first half of the twentieth century.

arrangement.p: Arrangement generally by type of material, arranged alphabetically within type.

did.unittitle: Commercial airlines (various countries, inc. Britain, France, Germany, the Netherlands, U.S.).
Air Maneuvers, military, various countries, prior to WWII.
Receptions, festivals, banquets prior to WWII: A-C.
Receptions, festivals, banquets prior to WWII: D-Z.
Coupes (spherical balloons): Gordon Bennett (1906-1913), Schneider, Deutsch.
Automobiles, including electric, Avion Laboratoire, challenges de tourisme, cinema, circuits.
Courses (routes), destroyed aircraft, eclipse 1905, factories, floating islands, ground lighting, hangers, human-powered flight, inventions, Laboratoire Eiffel, memorial services, monuments.
Monuments, indignia, museums, observatories, medical experiments, polar flights, refueling in air, saloons.
Schools for aviators, sports, Wellman Polar Expedition, wind tunnels, wings (experimental designs).
Bombs and missiles: Atomic Bomb, V1, civil air defense, guided missiles, Pearl Harbor, war photos (WWII).
Misc. Apparatus: radiocompass, photography, stroboscopy, etc.

scopecontent.p: Aircraft information arranged by country of origin and specific type of aircraft.

arrangement.p: Generally arranged by country of origin, and by type (balloons, dirigibles, gliders, hydroplanes, and model aircraft).

scopecontent.p: Information on companies that produced aircraft motors and engine.
Photographs and publications on aviators and aircraft designers.
